Award.AwardTitle: AMS Climate Studies: Fostering Climate Science Literacy and Promoting Minority Participation in the Geosciences (Track 2)
Award.AbstractNarration: The American Meteorological Society (AMS) Education Program is partnering with Second Nature, administrator of the American College and University President's Climate Commitment (ACUPCC), to implement the AMS Climate Studies course at 100 minority-serving institutions (MSIs) over a five-year period. This project focuses on introducing and enhancing geoscience components of MSIs that are ACUPCC signatories and/or members of the Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP). During the first four years of the project, AMS is conducting a weeklong AMS Climate Studies course implementation workshop for about 25 MSI faculty members per year. This workshop leverages the climate expertise of scientists from NOAA, NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, University of Maryland, Howard University, George Mason University and other local climate educational and research institutions. Faculty participants are immersed in the course materials, receive presentations from high-level speakers, and are trained as change agents for their local institutions. Following the workshop, the faculty will work on their local campuses to expand geoscience curricula, thereby bringing change from within. They will offer AMS Climate Studies as an introductory geoscience course in the year following workshop attendance, and be encouraged to implement the AMS Weather Studies and AMS Ocean Studies courses. AMS is conducting follow-up meetings with faculty as they work toward institutional geoscience curricula change. The major outcomes of this project will be a large network of faculty trained to be change agents in their institutions, sustained offering of AMS undergraduate courses within MSIs, and the introduction of thousands of MSI students to the geosciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The AMS Climate Studies Diversity Project (2011-2019) merged the national STEM initiatives of increasing diversity in the geosciences and enhancing sustainability curricula at colleges and universities nationwide through the study of climate and global change issues. The Project introduced the AMS Climate Studies introductory-level curriculum package in climate science and global climate change to 147 faculty members at 120 minority-serving institutions (MSIs). Many of the involved institutions are those working towards climate neutrality through the Second Nature President?s Climate Leadership Commitments and members the Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation network (LSAMP). MSIs included Federally-designated colleges and universities as well as those with significant underrepresented minority student enrollments.

 

MSI faculty participants attended a five-day professional development workshop in the Washington, DC area  (held 2012-15, 2017-18) that exposed them to the latest in climate research and operational science and detailed strategies for course implementation. NOAA, NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, and the Howard University Beltsville Center for Climate System Observation provided key field experiences. After the workshop, participants worked towards full climate course implementation on their local campuses. Many presented their work within the AMS Annual Meeting Symposium on Education.

 

The full AMS Climate Studies curriculum package, including an eTextbook, eInvestigation Manual, and RealTime Climate Portal, continues to provide faculty participants and their students with a dynamic educational environment where they investigate Earth's climate system using real-world environmental data. The components of Earth?s climate system emerge as interactive, defined through dynamic Earth processes and the principles that underlie how climate works, such as radiation and thermodynamic principles, planetary circulation and basic physical forces, and the world ocean. Climate change is explored with proxy records from the past, observations in the present, and with climate models into the future, looking at both natural and human influence. AMS Climate Studies details how human energy use and policy affect climate change, as well as how we are affected by it and how society views climate change. Participating MSIs locally offer the course in face-to-face, blended, or completely online learning environments.  With a focus on the most recent real-world climate data, the course is a primer for scientifically-literate participation in the discussion of climate change.

 

The AMS Climate Studies Diversity Project was based on the highly successful, NSF-supported AMS Weather Studies (2002-07) and AMS Ocean Studies (2005-09) Diversity Projects, which included 170 MSIs. About 50 MSIs introduced both the weather and ocean courses, synergistically affecting curricula changes on their campuses. Many of the institutions that offered Weather and Ocean also have faculty who participated in the Climate Diversity Project. In this way, AMS and its MSI partners have made a significant impact on geoscience education. As a whole, AMS Climate, Weather, and Ocean Diversity Project have activated more than 250 institutional licenses from MSIs and impacted more than 25,000 students.

 

The project external evaluator conducted a final longitudinal survey of Climate Diversity Project participants in early 2019 and received 48 responses. Individual implementation stories emerged, which support overall project success, as the vast majority implemented all or some portion of AMS Climate Studies. AMS originally considered full implementation of the Climate curriculum to be the singular mark of project success, but this viewpoint has expanded somewhat to include a wider variety of implementation strategies, ranging from offering of a stand-alone climate course to infusion of climate content into a preexisting course.

 

Success with the AMS Climate Studies Diversity Project led to collaborations with Consortium for Ocean Leadership (2014-2018) on the MSI-REaCH (Reconstructing Earth?s Climate History) program and the U.S. Ice Drilling Program Office (2015-present) on the School of Ice program to provide advanced professional development workshops for MSI faculty in paleoclimate with focus on research and data-driven and hands-on experience. The majority of the 32 MSI-REaCH participants and 48 School of Ice participants first participated in AMS Diversity Projects.


The intellectual merit of the AMS Climate Studies Diversity Project includes a substantive professional development opportunity for college faculty and introduction and enhancement of geoscience curricula at MSIs, including the Second Nature and LSAMP networks. The broader impacts of the Project include a large network of faculty enacting change on their campuses, participating in additional professional development, and introducing thousands of MSI students to the geosciences. This project has increased climate literacy and enabled faculty and students to contribute to public discussion of climate and global change topics. Climate course offering, as for the Weather and Ocean courses, will be sustained well-beyond the project funding period.
